user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_nonce_timestamp:
```c
static bool
get_nonce_timestamp (const char *const nonce,
                     size_t noncelen,
                     uint64_t *const ptimestamp)
{
  if (0 == noncelen)
    noncelen = strlen (nonce);

  if (true
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#if defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT) || defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
      )
    return false;

  if (TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN !=
      MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (nonce + noncelen - TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             ptimestamp))
    return false;
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
noncelen = strlen (nonce);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment calls the standard library function strlen(nonce). This does not call get_nonce_timestamp (neither directly nor indirectly), so there is no recursion. (Only if strlen were replaced by a user wrapper that called get_nonce_timestamp would indirect recursion be possible, but that is not the case here.)
